description.p: The Bandit leader breathing heavy as he and his band run for their lives. Why hadn’t he listened to the ferrymen who dropped them off. Why did he ignore the rumours, these questions haunted him as he gave the order to run faster . Suddenly a bellowing roar over head and the sound of clapping thunder and the ground shook as if it was impacted by a meteor and Standing before him and his band a firece looking Black dragon ready to destroy them.

A company of fighters closes in on hollow said to be the home of a emrald colored dragon. They have come with the intention of killing the beast before it can cause damage to the region. Little did they know the dragon was not alone. As they approached the hollow and caught glimspes of the dragon the ground erupted and they were soon entangled in a mass of vines. As the tried to free themselves a humanoid approached and said to them; “ We only wanted to be left alone.” The stranger then beheaded them one by one and returned to his activities.

All of these stories revolve around Dragon Riders, a diverse class designed for Dungeons and Dragons.Whether you serve the Rider’s Order, reject their teachings, or want a peaceful life of a nomad. All share their bond with the dragon who chose them, the unparalled masteries that come with this bond. And the adventure that awaits those who choose this class.

Riders spend years honing their fightning prowess, magical knowledge, and bond with their dragon. They are versatile enough to use any weapon handed to them, and skilled enough to understand magic and all it’s complexities. The one place you will always find a Rider is on the frontlines acting as the parties shield and sword.

As you build your Dragon Rider think about the choices you will make for the future. Will you serve the Order? There are many benefits to the being in the ranks of the Order, such as exclusive knowledge, access ro arms and armor you will finds no place else. Or will you reject the Order’s summons and try to forge your own destiny? Will you be a mighty Dragoon whose prowess with the spear is unmatched and complimented by the gifts bestowed upon them by their dragon? Will you be a Magus whose knowledge of magic can be considered limitless? What color is your dragon? How did the egg appear before you? All these things must be considered when making your Dragon rider.

You can make a Dragon Rider usinfg these quick suggestions; IF you are going with the Dragoon archetype First make Strength your highest score, Followed by Constitution,Dexterity,Charisma,Wisdom, and Intelligence last. If you are going with the Magus or Nomad archetypes, First make Intelligence your highest score, Followed by Constitution, Charisma , Dexterity,Wisdom, and Strength last. Lastly if you are going with the Cleric archetype, First make your highest score, Wisdom Followed by Constitution, Strength, Dexterity, Intelligence, and Charisma last.

description.p: At 3rd level, you choose an archetype that you stirve to emulate in combat styles and techniques. Choose between; Dragoon, Magus, Cleric, and Nomad. At 10th level a Rider may choose to change his archetype.

When you reach 4th level, and again at 6th, 8th, 12th, 14th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can’t increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.

Once you received the dragon egg you felt a great well of magic awaken in you. Augementing your martial prowess with ability to cast spells. you have a spellbook containing spells that show the first glimmerings of your true power.
You learn two cantrips of your choice from the Any spell list. You learn additional Any cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the Dragon Rider table.
At 1st level, you have a spellbook containing 6 1st-level wizard spells of your choice.

The Dragon Rider table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.

You prepare the list of Dragon Rider spells that are available for you to cast. To do so. choose a number of spells from your spellbook equal to your Intelligence modifier + your Dragon Rider level (minimum of one spell). The spells must be of a level for which you have spell slots(Unless you are a Magus).

For example, if you're a 3rd-level Dragon Rider, you have 2 1st-level spell slots. With an Intelligence of 16, your list of prepared spells can include six spells of 1st level only from your spellbook. Casting the spell doesn’t remove it from your list of prepared spells.

You can change your list of prepared spells when you finish a long rest. Preparing a new list of spells requires time spent studying your spellbook and memorizing the incantations and gestures you must make to cast the spell: at least 1 minute per spell level for each spell on your list.

Intelligence is your spellcasting ability for your Dragon Rider spells, since you learn your spells through dedicated study and memorization. You use your Intelligence whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Intelligence modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a Dragon Rider spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.

center.p: Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Intelligence modifier

description.p: At 7th level, the hatchling has matured into a 'Dragon Wyrmling', as described in the Monster Manual.

The dragon wyrmling is now a companion that accompanies you on your adventures and is trained to fight alongside you. The type of wyrming corresponds to the chosen dragon egg. Add your proficiency bonus to the wyrmling’s AC, attack rolls, and damage rolls, as well as to any saving throws and skills it is proficient in. Its hit point maximum equals the hit point number in its stat block or four times your Dragon Rider Level level, whichever is higher. Like any creature, it can spend Hit Dice during a short rest to regain hit points.

The wyrmling obeys your commands as best as it can On your turn, you can verbally command the wyrmling where to move (no action required by you). You can use your bonus action to verbally command it to take the Attack, Dash, Disengage, Dodge, or Help action.

If you are incapacitated or absent, the wyrmling acts on its own, focusing on protecting you and itself. The wyrmling never requires your command to use its reaction, such as when making an opportunity attack.

If you would be knocked prone, you fall straight to the ground and suffer the applicable fall damage. At the start of your next turn, you may use your action to land anywhere within half your move speed of the point you jumped from, making one melee attack against a target. If weapon is not a lance, attack is taken at advantage , If weapon is a lance and attack is successful, this attack is a critical hit, and target makes a strngth saving throw. Jump Strike can be used numbers of times equal to your Strength Modifier per Long Rest.

sheet.description: You perform a ritual over the course of 1 hour, which can be done during a short rest. The weapon must be within your reach throughout the ritual, at the conclusion of which you touch the weapon and forge the bond. Once you have bonded a weapon to yourself, you can’t be disarmed of that weapon unless you are incapacitated. If it is on the same plane of existence, you can summon that weapon as a bonus action on your turn, causing it to teleport instantly to your hand. You can have up to two bonded weapons, but can summon only one at a time with your bonus action. If you attempt to bond with a third weapon, you must break the bond with one of the other two.

description.p: Starting at 2nd level, you can use your action to magically assume the shape of a beast that you have seen before. You can use this feature twice. You regain expended uses when you finish a short or long rest.

Your druid level determines the beasts you can transform into, as shown in the Beast Shapes table. At 2nd level, for example, you can transform into any beast that has a challenge rating of 1/4 or lower that doesn’t have a flying or swimming speed.

You can stay in a beast shape for a number of hours equal to half your druid level (rounded down). You then revert to your normal form unless you expend another use of this feature. You can revert to your normal form earlier by using a bonus action on your turn. You automatically revert if you fall unconscious, drop to 0 hit points, or die.
While you are transformed, the following rules apply:

ul.li: Your game statistics are replaced by the statistics of the beast, but you retain your alignment, personality, and Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores. You also retain all of your skill and saving throw proficiencies, in addition to gaining those of the creature. If the creature has the same proficiency as you and the bonus in its stat block is higher than yours, use the creature’s bonus instead of yours. If the creature has any legendary or lair actions, you can't use them.

When you transform, you assume the beast’s hit points and Hit Dice. When you revert to your normal form, you return to the number of hit points you had before you transformed. However, if you revert as a result of dropping to 0 hit points, any excess damage carries over to your normal form. For example, if you take 10 damage in animal form and have only 1 hit point left, you revert and take 9 damage. As long as the excess damage doesn’t reduce your normal form to 0 hit points, you aren’t knocked unconscious.

You can’t cast spells, and your ability to speak or take any action that requires hands is limited to the capabilities of your beast form. Transforming doesn’t break your concentration on a spell you’ve already cast, however, or prevent you from taking actions that are part of a spell, such as call lightning, that you’ve already cast.

You retain the benefit of any features from your class, race, or other source and can use them if the new form is physically capable of doing so. However, you can’t use any of your special senses, such as darkvision, unless your new form also has that sense.

You choose whether your equipment falls to the ground in your space, merges into your new form, or is worn by it. Worn equipment functions as normal, but the DM decides whether it is practical for the new form to wear a piece of equipment, based on the creature’s shape and size. Your equipment doesn’t change size or shape to match the new form, and any equipment that the new form can’t wear must either fall to the ground or merge with it. Equipment that merges with the form has no effect until you leave the form.

Starting at 6th level, you can transform into a dragon with a challenge rating as high as your druid level divided by 3, rounded down. If you use Wild Shape to transform into a beast, you must follow the normal limitations on the Beast Shapes table.

description.p: At 9th level, you learn to use your wild shape in more precise methods. Channeling your connection beyond the restrictions of a total transformation, you sacrifice one use of your wild shape to more finely manifest a pair of dragon wings from your back in your base form. If you do not already have one or it is not reptilian in nature, you also grow a tail equal to half your height. These wings grant you a flying speed equal to your walking speed. This state retains the duration of a normal Wild Shape until level 14, at which time they last until you dismiss them. At level 18, they can be manifested and dismissed at will. Note: While it shouldn't be necessary to state, you cannot manifest these wings/tail while you are wearing any restrictive garments that would block them.

description.p: When you reach 3rd level, you augment your Arcane prowess with the ability to cast more powerful spells.

Spell Slots. The Nomad Spellcasting table shows how many spell slots you have to cast your spells of 1st level and higher. To cast one of these spells, you must expend a slot of the spell’s level or higher. You regain all expended spell slots when you finish a long rest.
For example, if you know the 1st-level spell shield and have a 1st-level and a 2nd-level spell slot available, you can cast shield using either slot.
